definition: to let things take their course/to take things as they come
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
smile (archaic)
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow
his/her/its/their/that/such/it (refers to sth preceding it)
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
correct/right/so/thus/like this/-ly

sentences.english: Some people have aims in their lives, some are just drifting along.
sentences.chinese: 有些人生活中有一定的目标，有些则听其自然。

sentences.english: If I were you, I should let things take their course.
sentences.chinese: 假如我是你，就听其自然。

sentences.english: We have let it alone more than most gardeners can.
sentences.chinese: 我们比绝大多数的园艺师更懂得听其自然。

sentences.english: Therefore, as the family say, why not let well enough alone?
sentences.chinese: 所以，就像她的家人所说的，干吗不听其自然呢？

sentences.english: My advice is to leave well alone.
We can't cure the disease; it must take its course.
sentences.chinese: 我们无法治愈这种病，只好听其自然了。

sentences.english: Leave the cure to Mother Nature.
sentences.chinese: 要想痊愈就听其自然吧。

sentences.english: Left to themselves, things tend to go from bad to worse.
sentences.chinese: 大凡事物，听其自然就会每况愈下。

definition: to let things take their course (idiom)/to leave it to nature/laissez-faire
not paying attention to anything (idiom); to idle time away
to follow/to go along with
futile endeavor (idiom)
(idiom) carefree/untroubled
to continue the same old routine/to carry on just as before/to procrastinate
to set to one side and ignore (idiom); quite indifferent/cold and uncaring
to pass by without showing interest (idiom)
if/supposing that/leisurely
even if/even though
one day's sun, ten days' frost (idiom, from Mencius); fig. to work for a bit then skimp/sporadic effort/lack of sticking power/short attention span
happen unexpectedly/turn out contrary to one's expectations
whatever you like/to do as one pleases
free and at leisure (idiom); unfettered
to let oneself go/to do as much as one pleases
to decide/to determine/established practice/(dialect) firmly resolved (to do sth)
